Good question. I hope that I=
 can provide a good answer. The reason why my code would care about the typ=
e of exception raised by the code that I have called is that there are some=
 exceptions that are non-terminal and that when received, my code will try =
to do something about it. Let's try an example:

An IllegalArgumentExceptio=
n means that I have messed up.

A JDBC Connection exception might mean that=
 the database is down, and that if my code is patient and retries in a few =
seconds, then everything may be connected again. (This is not unusual ... I=
 have found allowing for a number of retries to be a good thing when workin=
g with both database connections and also messaging systems)

A NullPointer=
Exception means nothing to anybody's code. Did I pass a Null value, or did =
the code that I called mess up or did it call some other code and that mess=
ed up? Who knows!?

And this is why my code cares about the exception that =
comes back. I can make programatic decisions based upon the exception that =
is returned, if the exception that is returned is meaningfull.

Hope this h=
elps.
